intro: Amphilophis intermedia var. acidula, commonly known as the sour apple tree, is a member of the Rosaceae family and is native to tropical regions of Africa. It is a small to medium-sized evergreen tree characterized by its elliptical, leathery leaves and fragrant white flowers. The fruit, which is typically small and sour, is used in traditional medicine and local cuisines. The plant is adapted to thrive in humid climates and is often found in forested areas. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and potential agricultural use.
